div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged beforehand. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gilbratar, Plymouth and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Moday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at he very convienient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is $22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
Passengers having paid full fare in one direction are allowed an abatement of 25 per cent on returnin within 12 months.
In addition to the above weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marsielles

div.head: the jeddah mecca railway
div.p: The idea of a Jaddah-Mrcca Railway is d< t as new as the attention wbioh it seems lately to h «ve evoked from certain qnarera, gays a correspondent in the "Morning Post." 0-man Nori Paoha, Vali if the Hedjaz, some eighteen years ago, was as anxioos to execote the prrjest as was th* Shu if of Mecca to oppose it 8herif 'tun er Rafik was brother to his predecessor who died by the hand of a beggar, and was born of the tribe from whiohMohamed Alisought an Emir when he deposed the ohief of the Dawi Ghalib from that position in punishment of his Wahabite sympathies He was as reactionary as his rival the P*cha was progressive; but the Pscha's attitude towards reform appeared so new and unaoeountable that the incredulity of the natives ie cot to be wondered at. The hostility tf the Emir effectively prevented the constru* tion of the railway, though even then the Bcheme fell far short of maturity, and he was further able to destroy the watsiworks with which the Vali had furnished thirsty Jeddah. On more than oue oooasion Binoe that time the realisation tf the projeot has seemed a possibility and half hearted negotiations have taken plaoe. Three years ago the Sheri f appear­ed ready to acquiesce and the initiative rf a British firm to meet with its reward in obtaining the oouceision, but before the Sherif's death, which ooonrred last August, the question had again fallen into abeyaooe.

The present ruler of the Holy City, 8herif Ali Pacha, is a man of enlightened views. The great Ataba tribe, of which he was a foster ohild, is entirely under his inflaenoe, and the Harbs and Arabs of the desert from Jeddah and Yambo to Mecca and Medina under his oontrol. Blackmailing has oeased, and the pil­grim of the future, so the optimists declare, is never again to be tha viotim of this final inci­dent of his journey. The tribes receive from Turkey a toll of grain, and grain and mousy from the Government of Egypt, on condition that the Hajj is not to be molested. This payment is the equivalent of the European Customs or ootroi, and is fair to both parties when it terms are adhered to. But the theory that the pilgrim should pass upon his way, free ot oharge Binoe his Government has already paid, is frequently very different from the praotioe ; for pleasant as it is to think of a solution so simple and effeotive, it must be remembered that these contributions have to pass throagh a number of bunds,and often are greatly dimin­ished in quantity at their destination. The Peraiaus also pay the tribes certain passage dues, known as ' rafik," from long-established oustom. When from one reason or another the stipulated payment is not forthcoming the Arabs refuse to argue and help themselves from the pilgrims Then, indeed, the troth of a man's faith, the sinoerity of his creed, under­goes an ordeal which muBt have proved too hard a test for any bat the most passionate conviction. A Hadji might come in peace from Java, a Bokhan might, and sometimes does, achieve his journey withoat changing his olothes until the oeremony of the Ihram, when at his journey's end the pilgrim dons his two white garments, bat from that mo­ment his hope of absolution risked ship­wreck ; the labour of his land or seafaring might be lost, for with the goal almost in sight the remission of sins had to be won across burning sands that held the prospeot of attack and the possibility of death or nakedness in a strange country. One resalt of constructing a railway wonld be to end this state of things.

At the present moment the Hedjaz line is advancing snrely and not very slowly, and seems likely to reach completion within three or fonr years. Though engineered by foreigner?, it is being constructed by the Turks, and will be a completely Ottoman railroad, and as saoh it must neceisarily grtatly facilitate the sup­pression of any revolt. It ie more than possible that as an offset to the Tnrkish line from Akaba the Sherif may be anxious to build a railway to Jeddah, which shall be entirely his, and whioh, after all, is only anticipating what must come when the Holy City is a terminas. Constantinople would probably be the obstacle to each a scheme, since it would entail condi­tions that the Saltan's Government might Dot appreciate. Unless its oonstrootion is pat into the hands of a German firm, its disadvantages and the possibility of its being even a danger will be urgently expounded to the Saltan by his European advisers. It will doubtless be impressed opon him that each a line must be another channel for foreign intrigue.

Bat the other side of the question will or perhaps is being pot before bis Maje-ty. Those arguments which suggest that 8 tarn bool would do well to anticipate Mecca, aud that, weie the matter in the hands of tha "honest broker," sore guarantees could be given, will not be forgotten

Russian Warship,
The Russian gunboat Koubanetz, armed with nine guns, arrived at Alexandria yester­day and will remain here about six days, when she will proceed to Jaffa and Beyrout. Discovery of Hashish.
An Armenian oi Bab-el Look, Cairo, was suspected of stealing a watch. On the polioe going to his house to'search for it, they found not tbe'watoh but a quantity of hashish !
Child Murder.
A native new-born child was found dead yesterday near Souk el Samak. The body was taken to hospital where the post-mortem examination showed that death had been brought about by foul means.
El Dorado.

The management of the El Dorado at Alex- dria inform ns that, in reiponoe to a general request on the part of the habitat of the establishment, they have deoided to display the evening telegram from Amerioa in the cafe itself.
A Mouled.

On Thursday evening the mouled of 8olei- mao el-Pharisi, the Prophet's friend, was celebrated at Boulao, according to the 8hadili rite. A laige tent was erectsd in front of the "Wtlli's" tomb and the ceremony was attend­ed by a large number of Sbadili Modems, who intoned their "dikr" and read the Prophet's life.
Prince Leopold in the Fayoum.

Prinoe Leopold of Battenberg, who is now residing at Ghezireh Palace Hotel previous to returning to Eogland, left last night for a couple of days' shooting on Lake Kairoon in the Fayoum province. His Highness is accom­panied by Major Wynne, Captain Warren, and two or three other gentlemen and will be back in Cairo on 8nnday night British Chamber of Commerce.

The March Journal of the British Chamber of Commerce of Egypt is, like its predecessors, fall of matter of interest to the British trader. Speoial interest is attaohed to the artiole describing the objeots of the society which has be6n recently formed for the protection of traders in Alexandria. The artiole on the advantages offered by the Chamber speaks for itself, and should awaken a wider interest in the Chamber at home. There are the naual other oontents of the journal, including a reviow of the imports during January.
Horrible Outrage.

A native of Korn Hamada, named Haggag Naglawi, was a few days ago in his house when Abd el Mouti el Zeghbi, of the same village, came and invjted him to meet some friends of his, who were, he said, anxious to ees him at the house of Abdel Moula Mekaid el Arabi. Naglawi promptly accompanied the messenger to the house, where nalf-a-doien men were waiting for him. These men, who had a grudge against Naglawi, fell upon him with their nabouta and beat him unmercifully, ending by impailing the unfortanate man with one of their nabouts. He was taken to his house in a precarious condition.
Imperial Ottoman Bank.

The Dews published lately by a Cairo con­frere, that the above bank had sold their premises in the 8haria El Manakh, is incorrect, for it has refused the offer of £l< 6,000 lately made. It is interesting to note that the property in question was bought by the late Mr. Moxley on behalf of the bank some 5 or 6 years ago from Mme. Veuve Mera Ismalum for £18,000; the improvements and addiuons, including cost of two shops fronting the main street, brought the total op to about £30.000. Previous to this the house was occupied for •isveral years by the General Officer Command­ing the Army of Occupation until the pur chase by the British Government of the hou e formerly belonging to Hassein Pacha Wassif in the Kasr-el-Doubara quarter.
Food Exhibition.

We have received a prrsppctus of the third Food Exhibition which is to be held at the Crystal Palace, London, lrcm April 7 to June 5 The exhibition, which promites to be a great success, will be a thoroughly repre- tentative one The C.pe Government Agri­cultural Department will be represented, and negotiations with the Natal Government pro­mise favourably towards that colony being represented in a like manner. Home firms have come in very well, especially the Bpas, hydros, health end plrasure resorts, which are being represented by a bay containing a large canvas iO feet high by 15 feet wide on which is portrayed the building or scene, in partioolar 8*ch screen by which the bays are bounded affords banging rcom for pictures showing interiors or ro nes aorronnding the place represented. The exhibition promises to be largertbap. any held of receut years, even eclips­ing last^ear's Colonial and Indian Exhibition, which was generally admitted a great snciess. Space is let at the rate of 4s. penq foot, 10ft. X 10ft =£20. All communications should he addressed to the assistant commissioner, Mr. Sydney F. Braybrooke-Weaton.

div.head:
Imperial Parliament
THE ARMY PROBLEM.
MR. SEELY'S MOTION REJECTED.

div.p: House of Commons. — 8ir H. Campbell- Bannerman appealed to Mr. See'y to withdraw the motion and pleaded for patience to allow Mr. Haldaue to examine the whole intricate problem. The Government's desire was to be as little provocative as possible and to do their utmost to prevent the growth of expenditure without prejudicing the efficiency of our mili­tary defences. The motion was rejected by 296 to 56 ; the minority consisting of Radicals and Labourites. The vote was then passed.

ACCUS ATIONS OF MASSACRE.

div.p: General Wood's report on the fighting in the Philippines was submitted to the Senate. A heated debate took plaoe in which the aocnsa- tions of a massacre were reiterated. {Renter)

A note from the Porte to the Persian Embassy declares that the Persian contentions regarding the frontier dispute are inadmissible. The question h»s become more acute. It is believed that Persia will be compelled to ask for mediation from Great Britain or Russia.

div.head: our special cables
div.p: ANGLO-SPANISH ENTENTE.
SCOPE OF THE AGREEMENT.
( Gazette'Speoial Servloe. )
London, Saturday.

The Rome correspondent of the "Eeho dj Paris'' learns from a diplomatic source that though no offioial alliance has been concluded between Great Britain and Spain, the Govern­ments at Loudon and Madrid have certainly come to an agreement analogous to that exist­ing between Great Britain, Franoe, and Italy. The understanding has reference not only to the question of Morocoo but in all probability to Mediterranean and European matters in general.

The correspondent adds that an An?lo- Spaniah entente would be weloomed in Italy as tending to thwart Germany's designs on ^'Mediterranean, and wonld be a cause of rejoicing in that the bonds of union between the western Power*, linked by oommon sympa­thies and interests, would be farther strength­ened.
AMERICAN STOCKS & SHARES.
THE PILGRIMAGE.

Dr. Suleiman Bey Hamada, de'egate of the Quarantine Board in the Hedj«z, telegraphs that great poverty exists among a large num­ber of the pilgrims, especially the 20,000 Indians, 11,000 Javanese, and 4,000 Algerians. These have suffered a great deal from hanger and ba«e been compelled to sleep on the ground in the open air, exposed to rain and cold and the burning snn. This has brought about an increase in the number of deaths among the pilgrims. There have been many deaths dae to ordinary diseases. Dysentery has not been so prevalent this year. The total number of deaths up to date is 4,676.

div.head: CONNAUGHT HOUSE CONCERT.
div.p: The very socoessfnl oonoert which was held at Connanght House on Thursday afternoon was its own reward for those who had arranged it, and for those who assisted in the programme. It is unnecessary to dwell on the good work done by the Y. W. C. A. in Cairo under the able management of M'ss Mao- lones and Miss Margeritson, and we were glad to see that bo large an andienoe had assembled to enjoy the very varied programme provided for their amusement. The concert was held under the patronage of Lady Cromer, who was present at it, and among the andienoe we noticed Lady and Miss Hemming, Mrs. Bullock, Mrs. George Royle, Dean and Mrs. Botcher, and many others well known in Cairo 8ooiety. The programme was a long one, though of a very varied nature, for besides vocal items there were also solos for the piano, violin, 'oelio, and harp, Mrs. da Boolay being unavoidably absent, the concert was opened by Mrs. Shields, who, as Miss Boyd Carpenter, has assisted at various of the Y. W. C. A. oonoerts in previous years, and her performance was followed by that of Miss Mary Lefroy who contributed some very delicately rendered vinlin solos. Mrs. Ronssio s mg two songs,the latter of whioh. "Devotion/' was much appreciated, and Mrs. Nolan's performances on the hsrp were heard with great attention. She played Thomas's "Reverie'' in a delightfully eympathetio manner, and her rendering of Hasselman's "Ballade" was also particularly pleasing. Miss Bollock favoured her audience with a graoefnl rendering of '0 lovely Night," and Herr Otto's solos on the 'oelio were received with every mark of satisfaction. Mis* Lefroy was happy in her selection of "Daffodils a-blowing." She has a charming voice, a fall and clear mezzo-soprano of good oompass, and foil of the vitality of youth. She sings her wordB with gr« at distinct­ness and would be heard with even greater advantage in a larger hall. 8he and her sister sang a coaple of«harming doets at the end of the programme which called forth an enoore, as her first song had also done in the earlipr part of the prog1 amnee. It is too rar'y tossy to what mone'ary extent this very excellent institution has gained from the prroeedsof the concert, but as the room was very well filled it is to be hoped that the endeavours of the energetic ladier who preside over it will have met with due recognition.

div.head: the akaba affair
div.p: STILL NO NEWS.
' ATTITUDE OF THE SULTAN.
v.From our Correspondent.)
Suez, Friday.
The erniser Nonr-el Bahr returned to 8a ez from Akaba last Thursday, and H.H.S. Aida sailed hence for Akaba yesterday afternoon with despatches and provisions for H.M.S. Diana.
The situation at Akaba seems to be unchang­ed, and all information is strictly withheld by all the crewp.
Says the "Globe" : —

There is one onrions point to be observed about the frontier dispute between Egypt and Turkey, which is that as Egypt is nominally one of the vilayets of the Turkish Empire the qaestion wonld seem to be not so mnoh one of the frontiers of two States as of the boun­daries of a province. But Egypt has been practically an independent State since the time of Mohamei Ali, and the frontiers in the Sinaitio peninsula were regulated as long ago as l4-40 by the Convention of London, which tamed the Egyptians ont of Syria. The Porte is bounl to respeot this Convention, and is powerless to violate its terms, but its aotion in the matter is doubtless direoted not so mnoh against Egypt as against this ooontry. Turkey has always viewed with the greatest dislike the extension of British infinenoe *in the Sadan, and the opening of Fort 3ndan has seemed to oall for some reply on her part The fortification of Akaba, at the head or the golf of that name, in connection with the Hedjaz railway, will, it is hoped by the Sal­tan's advisers, neutralise the increased influ­ence of Great Britain in the Red Sea brought about by Port Sudan, and it is this, rather than the prospect of the fl ink attaok on the Sinaitio peninsnla, which has prompted the move. At the bottom of the whole thing is the Saltan's fear that he is losing ground in the Holy Places, and the Hedjaz railway and the Akaba inoident are the means by which he hopes to hold his own in the eyes of the Faithful.

div.head:
KHEDIVIAL AGRICULTURAL
SOCIETY.
div.p: (From our Correspondent).
Tant>h, March 14.

A meeting of the Khedivial Agricultnral Society was held at Shebin el Knm on the 11 th inst., under the presidency of H.E. the Moudir of Menoufieb. Many omdehs, notables, and farmers of Shebin, Tala, and Quesna Markazes were preseat. A similar meeting wa9 held on the lvth inst. at Menonf, where the omdshs of Menouf and Asbmoon attended and the Moudir presided.

At 11 a.m. the Moudir opened the proceed­ings. He explained to those present the objeots of the meeting which was called to deal prin­cipally with the reappearance of cattle plague in the country and the necessity for oaltivating cotton on only one-third of the whole area possessed by every person.

His Excellency, leaving the second point for Hosny Eft., the seoretary of the society (whom be rightly described as being a specialist in agricultural matters), dealt with the first point. He stated that it was every man's duty to combat the ravages of cattle plague, who«e reappearance in Egypt he regretted very mnob. He advised them to send information to the authorities as soon as any suspicions case oc­curred. To show the assembly how the Govern­ment works for the good cf the people, the Moudir read to them the circular issued by the Government to the effeot that it was ready to pay the owners of any cattle killed by the authorities. He also pointed ont to them the advantage and necessity of inoculation.

At the conclusion of the Moudir's speech Hosny Eff. rose ard dwelt on the second snb- jeot. He stated that th9 continuation of an excess in ootton plantation wonld one day make Egypt a welcome home for famine. Picturing • o the audience the benefit of allot­ting one-third only of their plantations for ootton, Hosny Eff. stated that by adopting this 8''heme the following advantages wonld be derived —1. The fertility of the land wonld be maintained ; 2. A good way of p'anting other orops such as beans, eto, wonld be found easy and attainable; 3. Land soaking will not have an opportunity to exist ; 4. Water will be spared to enable other crops to be grown ; 5. Workmen's wages will deorease ; 6. The dampness of the atmosphere will be hindered and thus no insects nor malarial diseases will threaten the country (as a rule, the larger the ootton area is, the damper the olimate grows) ; 7. Cotton will be improved and threads would be rendered smooth and long ; P. When the ootton is bo improved it will naturally be sold at a higher price ; 9. There will be an inorease in the wheat and maize crops and oonseqnent- ly the prices of viotnals for man and beast will fall; 10. By the fall of prices cattle oan easily be reared and well served ; 11. The feddan, though it yields at present six kantars, will in each a case produce at least eight; 12. A rise in the price of land will, as long as it gives a good harvest, naturally ensue.
The secretary's recommendations ware evidently taken to heart and are likely to have a good effeo4.

Lord and Lady Meath are staying at the Hotel Bean-Rivage at Ramleh Lord Meath, who is in his sixty-fifth year, has for many years been aotively engaged in sooial and philanthropic work, and among other posts he holds the arduous one of President to the Chnrch A-my, of which the Rev. Wilson Carlile is the able secretary. Be ides being Earl of Meath he holds the titles of Baron of Ardee, Ireland, ard also Baron of Chawortb, Eaton Hall, Hereford, and he owns property to the extent of some 3^,000 aoras. He started life as olerk in the Foreign Office in 1863, but five years later he exchanged into the Diplomatio Service, and served in tnrn at Frankfort-on-Main, Berlin, the Hague and Paris. In 1874 he became the first Hon. Seoretary to the Hospital Saturday Pnnd, and in 1879 he also took a leading part in the formation of fh£ Yonng Men's Friendly 8ociety. He was_*hd founder of the Metro­politan Poblio Garden Association, and the first President to the British College of Physical Education.

Lord Meath was elected Alderman of the London County Council in 1889, and was the first chairman of the Parks Committee. He was the first president of the Churoh Reform Asso­ciation, as well as the Dablin Philanthropic Reform Association, and it was be who founded theLsds' Drill Association. He hrs published many books and pamphlets on philanthropic subjects, and is one of the greatest sccial refor­mers of the day. He ow s a beautiful place in Bray and another in Rith dram,and bis English country home is in O .tershaw, Chertsey. Lady Meath was Lady Mary Jane Maitland, daugh­ter of the llrh Etrl of Lauderdale. Since arriving in Alexandria L'dy Meath has been taking great interest in the M C.L. Industrial School for the Blin 1, of wh:oh institution she is the foundress and mainstay. Lord Meath has been spending a few days at the Savoy, Cairo, bat has now returned to Ramleh.

div.head: Billiards
div.p: CAIRO MARKERS' TOURNAMENT.
Final Round.

At 9.21 the first match of the third and last round played between Syer and Percy began, the latter opening with a safety mi«s in banlk. After a miss by his opponent Percy soored 2 but failed at an easy winning hazard off the red. Syer responded with a nine break, ending by "shopping*' his opponent and giving a double miss in banlk. Play continued quietly for a time, both being rather nervons and no important break was noted till the score was at 84-82 in favour of 8yer, who overtook his opponent with a well-compiled 17. With Percy 14 behind Syer passed the 100 with a sixteeu break, to wnion Percy replied with a good twenty and led again by five. Shortly afterwards Syer soored a neat 26, Percy responding with 12. Soore : 127-117, Peroy ahead. A safety mise from Percy resulted in a splendid lo3ing hazard off the white into the middle pooket by Syer, who oontinned till nineteen. Both went t) the table several times without notable result till Syer gave a break of 26, Peroy only sooring nine. Soores: 188-174 in favor of Syer. Shortly afterwards Syer pa-sed 200 with a break of 18, followed by 23, 39, and 17, while Percy conld only mnster 14. With the scores at 296-169 Syer made two cannon and ran out an easy winner by 131 points.
SYER v. FLOWERS.

After the usual safety misses Flowers was first to soore with a brace. No break of any note occurred till the same player soored a very neat 84, which he followed up with eleven and 19, Syer meantime only scoring 2. Flowers passed the hundred well in advance of the handioap and with subsequent breaks of 20, 12, 8, and 8 seemed to have a good winning chanoe. Syer, however, then compiled a remarkable 76 full of capital strokes and so came within two of his rival, scores being 222-220. Play continued to be even till Syer got away with a break of 28 : after two resultless visits to the table Flowers compiled 18, to which Syer replied with 12 and then left Flowers 23 behind. Soores : 283-260. With seventeen 'o make Syer ran out winner- with breaks of 5 and 13. Final soores : 800-267. At the conclusion the match, Mr. Mansfield, on behalf of Raoot Bey Sabit, presented Syer, as winner of the tournament, with an eaamelled silver o>ga- rettejoase and Percy, as runner up, with a stop watob.

div.head: Football
div.p: Victoria College F.C. St. Andrew F.C.

Played on Saturday afternoon on the College ground. The Saints won the toss, and eleoted to kick with the sun behind them. The game from the outset was of a fast nature and both b ick divisions had their work out out to keep the opposing forwards from getting through. The College were the first to appear dangerous, but the f >rwards were a little off in their shoot­ing. Mace, however, was in pretty safe mood between the stioks and when the College men did at last find their shooting boots they learned that the Saints' costodian was not to be f mod napping. The visitors were not loDg in settling down, and thanks to soond support from the half-back line, which bad been ma­terially strengthened by the inclusion of Shep- phard and Henley, the forwards were enabled to get moving toward Saba. Mustard, however, who always seems to have the happy knaok of getting in the way of well-meant passe?, didn't give the visitors much opportpnity for testing Saba, and whan a chance for shooting did pre­sent itself the forwards were not allowed aDy time to steady. Qoal kicks were numerous at both ends, a fact which indicates pretty fairly the fast nature of the game throughout. At half-time neither side had managed to score.

On resumiog, the play became even faster than before. Yaken was prominent again and again in takiog the ball into the Saints' terri­tory. His centres were well-timed and well- judged but Henley kept a careful eye on Morrison, giving him very little chanoe to get at Mace. Shepphard initiated a smart run on the lef-, which brought the visitors down upon Saba. Rofe put smartly into oentre, and Keill had the ball past Saba, thus scoring the first and only goal of the match. This reverse roused the College, and they tried harder than ever to get through Mace's charge, and although several s iff shots were sent his way the visitors' custodian handled well and cleared cleverly. A high dropping shot looked like setting the teams again level but it fell just behind ths bar. Play was for a time confined <o one side of the field, the ball repeatedly going into touch. From a mis-kick by Mustard Jones got through and teited Saba with a rooket but Saba saved smartly. Time ariived with the tore unaltered, the Saints thus running out viotors by the odd goal.
The f dlowing were the teams : -
Victoria College F.C. F. Saba, A. Mustard, A. Verny, G. Valaisopoulo, A. G. Lias A. N'ah&s, M. S Yaken, M. Abou-el-Azz, A. Mor­rison, A. E. Aubrey, and Y. Cheori.
St. Andrew F.C. :—Mace, Hopkins, Cowie, Bright, Henley, Shepphard, Constantinidis, Tullooh, Keil, Jones, and Rofe.

div.head: helpless with rhumatism
div.p: The case of Mr. George West, of 161, Eve­lyn Street, Deptford, London, England, is excaptionally interesting. Mr. West says :— "I used to th;nk I phoald go mad with the constant sutferi ig from kidney trouble and rheumatism. I could get no peace, no rest, no comfort, day or night. It made people ill to see me struggling to try to walk. My back was so weak that I thought it would break ia two, and at last I lost the nse of my limbs, and my feet had do feeling in thun. The pains in my back were just as th > >gh some >ne we'e prilling the joints out of the sockets. The ih jumaMsm doubled ins up. and I need to wish I could die and be out of it all. It was awful to sea him trying to walk, and at last he could only just manage to move about by using sticks. Rheumatism shows a lax condition if the kidneys, and the presence of nrio aoid in the system in great excess. Urine is S adding and Painful in pass­ing, thare is a feeling of Weariness and Pain intheB.ck, and the patient Aches in every Limb.

Doan's Backache Kidney Pill c are successful in curing these kidney troubles because they dissolve the crystallised uric add and area, and inorease the fl >w of nrine, by which tho imparities are flushed out of the system, and the kidney organism cleansed and restored to health.

Rarement contraste a dtd ausai frappant qae oelui qae nons avons it relever entre le ddbut de cette semaine et eeloi de sa devan- ciere : An lien de cette course an clocher vers la hansse, sans rime ni raison, qui doos avait port^a en deox 6danoes jnequ'k 20 1; 16 poor le Mars et dont noos parliona dans notre der- nidre revne, o'est à on veritable aflfolement dans le sens de la baisse qae noos avons assists cette fois et dont la oonsdquence a dtd de noas faire reonler dans la matinee de samedi à 18 5/8, soit 17/32 de perte sur la oldtnre de la veille.—Poor on manvais commencement, cola dtait soffisant et n'enssent dtd lea raohats de oeox qui avaient profit4 de l'excitation des jonrs prdcddenta poor vendre, cette ddbandade ee serait sfirement ohaDgde en paniqne.

Qaant anx causes qui ont provoqud ce re­virement soudain, elles sont an numbre de trois: La diminution sensible des embarqoements dans la journde de vendredi, faiBant prlaager sous ce rapport one petite semaine, la continuation des gros arrivages de l'intdrieur et les nouvelle# d'Amdrique nous apportant 12 points de baisse. Quoique rapide, le mouvement, du moins pour oe jour-lk, dtait amplement justifid par les sos-dits motifs qui n'dtaient pas ddpourvus d'importance et, au moment de l'affiohage de* oonrs, la tendance dtait si mauvaise qne, si dans l'aprks-midi le marohd avait dtd ouvert. noua aoriona certaicement eu une nouvelle dd- route non moins marquee, sortout qae Liver­pool nous est veuu si pen eDOOurageant avec sea ventes de 100 d'Egyptien, sans compter les 10/64 de baisse qui les aocompagnaient.

Grice anx realisations qui avaient eo lieu et avaient qoelque pen alldgd udo quantity de petita spdculateurs, et au rdpit qae nous avODS eu jusqn'k lundi matin, le parti de la haosae a pu en qoelque sorte se rallier ; aasai et quoiqu'en baisse à 18 1/2, l'ouverture de la seconde journde a dtd moins manvaise qae oe que Ton attendait. Jusque vers midi nous nous sommes maintenos, en pivotant autoor, an prix en qnestion, mais à l'arrivde de l'avant bourse de Liverpool, jugde on ne peut plus favorable et comme fonrniesant un bon prdtexte, une tentative de poosser les coors a eu lien et aveo plein succks, car à 1 beore nous dtions k18 13/16 et le soir k19 1/32. Lrsplas forts iutdre&fcds n'espdraient pas tant pi si vite !

Le len^emain, sous 1'iDfluenoe des mdmes motif* qui avaient si loordement pe*d sur la aituat'On dans la matiude de samedi, soit pe tites expr rtatioDS, gros arrivages et une nou- ^ lebabse de 15 points en Amdrqne, on a oi<vert olme et indicia sur la base de 19 1/32 pour le Mars, poor fldcbir gradoelltment à 18 27/ 2, m**is tout d'on coop or e mai oeuvre I* coo m D' d à 8a degsiner qui a fait rem'»nter a Mnrs A 19 3/32. Tootefois, dans I'atods-mid1 U faiblesse h repr s e dessu* et la olOture di soir a eu lieu à 19 1/8.

Mercredi, la question des petites expeditions et riea arrivages a dtd mise de cd d,# et re prenant en oonsiddrarion qae a olfltur* d'Aadriqne, en reprise d'oueditaine de point., on addbutd a 9 5/32, pour reooler k19 1/32 et remonter k19 5/16 ; mais dans la seoorin udance de la journde le* choses sont allien aass' m*l qne la veille an soir et oela kcause de is manvaise teuue de l'Amdrioain, qu'ou n'a pas bu ft'expliqner, mais qui a fim qnand mdme par impreshionner toot le monde. En nomme, le daminr ooors afficbd k6 b. p in. a dtd ds 18 31/32.

liter, par suite de la baisse d'Amdriqne et > caoi-e du petit ch fire des emharquements at - noncd par la Donane, la journde a commence faible a 18 15/16. mais le manque de vendeur tdrieux kce niveau a bientot provoqud mu amelioration qui s'est main ten oe et s'est mdm accentude plos tard an point de noos porter »

Aajoord'hoi, poor finir la semaine, la tenue do marché a dtd extratrdinairement sgitde aartOQt dans l'aprds-midi sur des raohats do ddooovert, dit on, et le dernier coors offioiel. qui reprdaente en mdme temps à pen prd* le maximom pratiqod a dtd de $ 19 23/32 Boit une gvance acqoise sur vendredi dernier de 9/16 de tallari et de 1 7/32 sur le plus baa prix de lundi.

Comme on le voit, les hanssiers n'ont pas ddsarmd et n'ont gndre I'air de vonloir en core renoncer à la partie : l'bdsit&tion et les bruBqQes flactaations qne Ton oonstate de temps à aatre s'expliqoent par le haut niveau auqoel nous sommes, mais au fond la spicu­le1011 considdre sa position comme tenable jasqoe vers 1'dchdaDce juillet, et le temps semble dtre le point prinoipal pear elie. Quelqoe ennemi que l'on soit des f&ussei po sitions, if faot bien reoonnaltre que, poor cette fois du moins, elle n'a pas tout-k-fait tort de montrer de la tdnaoitd. II est à pea prd8 eertain que la finale laissera des ddboires, at®° les dnormes reports payda et ceux qui seront encore payds, et la rdaotion ddfinitive qui ne mar qoera pas de se prodaire le joor ofc il s'agira de liqoider, mais eDtre temps l'irn prdvu peat toujours venir en aide ! Da reste elle semble convainone que quand la qoestior rendement de la rdoolte ne sera plus du disoutable, la situation lui sera plus favorable par le fait qu'elle arrdtera la latte qae la filature est eu train de loi livrer, ce qui fera disparaltre le caoohemar des miees à disposi Uon ou leur rdduotion kdes quantitds insi gnifiautes.

Tout est possible, certes, mais dans oes con­ditions on se moDtre peat-dtre un pea trop optimiste quant à l'avenir, oar l'expdrtenoe du passd nous pronve que dans les oiroonstances difficiles le consommateur trouve le moyen de s'arranger. Ddjk le Continent qni, inoontesta- blement, n'a pas achetd toot ce qui lui dt&it indispensable, non seolement a fait antioiper I'expedition d'une partie de ce qui devait lui dtre envoyd en mai, et oela ponr ne pas dtre forcd de venir sur le marché au moment aotuel, mais Ton sffirme aussi que plus d'nn filatenr a ddcidd de renoncer à l'emploi de 1'EgyptieD, en lui substituant le bon amdricain qui n'est pas aa88i rare qu'on le disait, tandis qne ceux qui sont sons oontrats, rdduiraient leurs besoms anx engagements existants.

La filature anglaise ne ponrrait pent-dtre pas en faire antant, ni d'one fa^on aossi oompldte, mais 8es engagements dtant converts, elle pent tirailler, retarder ses retraits et spdonler en attendant sur les oontrats, oomme elle semble le iaire depnis qne les conrs ohez nons ont ddpased le nivean de 20 tallaris, car, sauf la crainte de voir le voisin Ini enlever sa marchan- dise, rien ne l'empdcherait dventnellement de faire mdme livrer le ooton qn'elle a ioi, dans I'espoir de le reprendre aveo bdndfioe qnand la spdcolation devra liqoider.
Quant kl'Amdriqne, elle ne vent pas en­tendre parler du ooton dgyptien pour le restam de la campsgoe et se contente de se taire ex [ ddier ce qu elle a prdcddemment achetd.

Malgrd toot, cependant, il ne fant pas pren­dre les ohoses d'une fa^on trop absolne, mais en Bourne il y a pour le moins dans la manidre d'agir de la filatnre des indices qn'il serait bon de ne pas perdre de voe.

On a rdpandu à la Boarse le bruit qne 1» Produce Association, aprds nouvelle enqud e □r la question de la rdcolte avait ddcidd d'a mender sa dernidre estimation. Il n'en est rieD; mais oe qui n'a pas dtd fait par elle, l'a dtd par d'antres et notamment par notre confrdre indi «dne, "Le Bassir" qni s'oooupe sdrieusement de toot ce qui peat intdresser le oommeroe et qai, obligeamment et avant la publication de son rapport, a bien vonlu nous communiquer en ddtail le rdsnltat de ses investigations: Le rdanmd est qne la rdcolte ne ddpassera pas les 6 Millions de Cantars an grand maxi­mum. Jucqu'ioi, personnellement, nons avons dtd des plus rdcaloitrants k croire à on pareil chifire, mais devant 1'uDanimitd de l'o- pinion sur oe point, corroborde d'ailleors main- renant par nos informations privdes, nous de vons faire amende honorable et admettre la vdraci d de cette estimation. Cinquante on mdme cent mille quintaux de pins ue change raient dventnellement pas le fond. Il e?t vrai qne les arrivages sont encore de nature à faire encore douter de la chose, n ais il est de fan que la plupart des osines d'dgrenage ont ddjk lermd et qne oelles qui sont encore en aotivitd, ■'ont gu£re de travel ponr an-delk d'une quinzaine de jourf. Les hanfs prix ODt ton uneue t aitud la marcbaudise plus vite qu'on ne le pensait.
La nonvelle rdcolte ne marohe plus de cor»- ert avec l'ancienne : Paitie de 16 /16. el>

Toot allait bien à la oonfdrence marooaine ; depuis samedi dernier Reuter et Havas nous apportaient obaque jour one amelioration sen­sible de la sitaation; Guillaume II faisait mdme preuve hier matin d'un esprit de concilia­tion tonchant, en cddant sur nombre de points au sojet de la police, lorsqne soudain hier soir, le veut ohangeait de direotion, une rapture de- venait imminente suivant Renter, et suivant Havas les ndgooiations snbissaient un arrdt. Heareosement ponr le marohd, oes variations des agenoes ne sont pas noovelles et lenrs boni- ments optimistes de ces jonrs derniers n'ont pas plos ddtermind la bausse que lenrs dd- pdches alarmistes ne vont entralner la baisse. On l'a bien vu oe matin snr notre pises oh Tooverture B'est eflfeotnde en pleine efferves­cence sur les priDcipales valenrs. Le peu de ca« qn'on fait maintenant des brnits sans fonde- meDt venant d'Algdsiras est d'aillenrs pleine* ment jm-tifid par les nonvelles oontradiotoires pnblides jusqu ioi.

Voioi, dans ses grandes lignes, le bilan de la semaioe dcoulde : Samedi, les petites valenrs qui avaie* t fait furenr durant la semaine prdeddente, restent eocore en vogue ; mais, dds lundi, l'attention de la spdoolation se concentre sur l'Urbaine et le Comptoir à la nouvelle de prochaines dmissions de oes socidtds. Le lendemsin, simnltandment aveo elles, la National Bank rentre en Iigne aveo aon titre de banqne d'Etat : puis, le jour suivant la Nungovioh et la Delta Light. PROSPECTUS.
This Company has been formed with the object of carrying od financial, railway, tramway, eleotrio, building, land and development, iudastrial, and shipping business in Egypt and the Soudan.
This Company will acquire under an Agreement hereinafter mentioned between this Company and the Egyptian Contract Company, Limited: —

The controlling interest, namely, abont foar-fifehs of the Capital Actions and Obligations, of the Fayonm Light Railways Company (Sooilrl Anonyme). which railway is situated in the Fayonm Province, near Cairo, and is now 168 kilometres, or abont 105 miles, in length.

The Railway Company holds its concession from the Ezypti&n Government with a guarantee (subjeot to terms and conditions set forth in the oonoession) that the net receipts as therein defined shall amount to £36 per kilometre actually workei (not inclod ing sidings, etc.), being three per oent on £1,200 per kilometre, the basis agreed by the Government. The Concession is for a period of 70 years from 19<>2, subject however to the right of the Government to expropriate the railway after 25 years on the terms of the oonoession, and provides that the Government shall not grant rights to any other concessionaires for the construction and working of narrow gauge agricultural railways in the province of Fayonm.
With regard to the past administration of the Railway, Lord Cromer, in his Report on Egypt, 1904, says:

"As regards the Fayoom Railway; 518,000 passengers and 145,0^0 tons cf goods were carried, as compared to 479,000 passengers and 1» 7/00 tons of\goods in «903. The nett reoeipts were L.E. 9,840, as compared to LE. 5,200 in 1903. yhe proportion of working expenees to gross receipts fell from 72 percent, to 60 per oent.

"All these railways have, in faot, profited by the general/ rise in the prosperity of the country. The two first-named, but I regret to say not the lapt (the Fayonm Company), have also probably profited by efficient management.
"In the case of all these lines, numerous complaints are made of irregularity in the times of anival and departure of the trains.

'The Government Inspector reports very onfavoorab'y rfthe Fayoom Company. wh;ch stands greatly in need of a competent manager. 'Th-r Staff ' he writes, 'appear to be entirely out of hand, and the Traffic and Locomotive Departments have both apparently been left to run by themselves ' In his opinion, ibe inorea»e in the receipts i», in this ease, entirely due to the great increase in the prosperity ot the Fayouir, and not to the »ffiuient working of the Company."

According to the Railway C mpany'g Batano* Sbeeffor the year ended 2^th Febroary 1905, the gr» ss receipts of the Railway were L.E. *3.096. and the profits L.E. 8 002: Lord Cromer's Report, above quoted, states the net receipts for 1904 to be L E. 9,840.

With regard to the fatare the Directors believe that, under effi ie »t management and with expenditore on betterments, the enterprise will have important and remunerative results the more so as the Egyptian Government is direct'y intererel in its snccess, being entitled to receive 50 per cent, of all grosu rncepts above £225 per kilometre.

The population of the Province of Fayonm is rapidly increasing and the fertility of the land is well known. In view of the*e facts and if the rights of the Paynutu L'Rht Railways Compa* y in oonneo'ion with the Construction of Light Railways in the Provinoe, the Directors believe that operations oan be pr fitably exte ded.

The Crldit Glnlral Lilgeois, before asfociating it+elf with this Company, received a fuli report from Messrs. Prison and Desoer, whom it had sent out to make en investigation and report. This report can be seen, as mentioned below, at the cffio?s of the Solicitors of the Compary.
The Directors propose to soqaire lands suitable for agriculture and to improve the same with a view to their pr Stable re-sale or leasing.

The Directors are of omnion that there is a future for wa+er ♦n»ffij in Egypt, and will consider ih-question of Nile Navigation, especially in the Delta. With op-to-date material and equipment, this Industry should prove remunerative.
Management.

The Compat y has obtained the services of M'. 8. Sandison de Biliuski as Manager in Egypt, for five years from the date of incorporation of the Company. Mr. S. 8. de Bilinski has had many years' experience of financial and commercial business in Turkey and Egypt, and has for over three years been Secretary to ti c Daira Smieh Company. Limited, the largest and most soccestful land Company in Egypt. He will receive a salaiy of £1,(00 per annum, plus travelling aDd out-of-pocket expenses, and 1$ per cent on the yearly net profits of the Company by way of further r. moDeration.
General.

The minimum subscription has been fix*'d by the Attides of Association at £100,000 but the subscription of 70,Oi 0 shares of £5 each has been guaranteed at the issue price of £5.5s. at a cemmissim of 3j per cent, on the nominal value of the shares by two Contraots made by the Company, the one with Messrs. Stee'e, Lockhart & Oo., of 62, London Wall, E C., and the othlr with Messrs. Lambert & Ralli, of Brasse's, and the Credit Glnlral L:lgeois of Lilge and Bmsaels, both dated Marcu 5th, 1906, by which Messrs. 8teele, Lockhart & Co. guarantee the sabsoription of 20,000 shares, and Messrs. Lambert & Ralli, and the Credit Glnlral Lilgeois, the subscription of 5o,000 shares. The Company has also made an Agreement dated Maroh 5th, 1906, with Messrs. Steele, Lockhart & Go., whereby that firm has agreed in consideration of the sum of £l 1,500, to pay all preliminary expenses connected with the formation of the Company, and the issue of this prospectus down to the fi st ge: eral allotment of shares (other than brokerage aud underwriting commissions and costs, expenses and stamp duty on transfer to the Company, which will be paid by the Com­pany) ; they will retain the difference, if any, between the aotaal expenses and the said snm, and will bear any exoess which may be payable. These expenses are estimated at £ll,5r0 The firm under the said oontract ha9 the first right to underwrite or guarantes at the price of issae to be fixed by the Company for a like coufmission of 3| per oent. on the nomiual>moant thereof all chores of *he Company which the Company may from time to time determine to offer for public sabsoription and to oausa to be underwritten. The Company will also pay a brokerage of Is. 8d. per share on all shares applied^ for by the public, other than underwriters, and allotted, on applications bearing Bankers' or Brokers' stamps. The amount payable by the Company for brokerage, and the costs, expenses and stamp duty on transfer are estimated at £2,500.
The following Directors are interested as sab-underwriters, and each will receive 2£ per oent. commission on the amount of the shades underwritten by him, as follows : —
J. Dallison Alexander 1,000 shares, Georges C&rlier l.OCO shares, Jules G. Frlion 1,000 shares, Florent Lambert 1,000 shares, and Edouard Wiener 1,000 shares.
The Articles of Association eontain the following provisions

The qnalifioation of a Direotor shall be the holding of shares of the nominal value of £500. The remuneration of the Directors shall be at the rate of £250 per annum eaoh. with an extra £lf 0 per annum for the ChainnaD, and in addition thereto the Direotors shall be entitled to receive by way of farther remuneration for eaoh year in which a dividend of at least £5 per cent, per annum is paid to the Shareholders, a sum equal to 5 per oent. upon the amount qf the profits remainirg after snch dividend at the rate of 5 per oent. per annum has been paid ; all such further remuneration to be payable when the profits in exoess of suoh dividend at the rate of 6 per oeDt. per annom are divided among the Shareholders, and to be divided between all the Direotors in office at the date of snch division of profits, bat so that the Chairman for the time being of the Company shall receive out of suoh iurther remuneration twioe as much as eaoh ordinary Direotor, other than the Vice-Chairman (if aDy) of the Company, and that the Vice-Chairman (if any) for the time being of the Company Bhali receive out of snch further rrmuneration one and one-half times as muon as eaoh ordinary Director ; the ordinary Direotors shall, inter se, be entitled to share equally in soob further remuneration. The Company in General Meeting may at any time, and from time to time, vote to the Directors or any of them snch additional remuneration as may be thought proper, and snch additional remuneration may be by way of a fixed sum, or by way of a percentage on profits or otherwise as may be determined. Provided that a majority of the Directors may by resolution reduce the amoont, or waive, or postpone the payment of their remoDe'ation or ary part thereof; any snoh resolution to bind the minority. An alternate Direotor appointed under Artio'e 91 hereoi shall not as suoh be entitled to any remuneration. Each Direotor shall be reimbursed his reasonable travelling and oot-of pocket i xpenses in attending Board Meetings or whilst otherwise employed on the basiness of the Company. Any Director may be employed, by or hold ary office of profit under the Company, other than that of Aaditor of the Company, and if any Direotor shall be called upon to go, or reside abroad, on the Company's business, or to serve on any Committee or Committees of Direotora which may be appointed for the purpose of conducting, negotiating or oarrying out any particular business, contract or undertaking, or otherwise perform extra services, the Board may arrange with snch Direotor for snoh speoial remuneration for snch services either by way of salary, commission or the payment of a stated snm of money, as they shall think fit, in addition to his ordinary remuneration as a Direotor. TheDinorors may from time to time appoint one or more of their body to be a Managing Direotor or Managing Directors of the Company, either for a fixed term or without any limitation as to the period for which be or they is or are to hold snoh office, and msy from tjmQ to time remove or dismiss him or them from iffioe and appoint another or others in bin or their place or places. The remuneration of a Managing Direotor (snbj not to any agreement between him and the Company), shall be fixed by the Direotors, and may be by way of salary, commission, percentage or participation in profits, or by any or all of these modes.

div.head: CREDIT LYONNAIS
div.p: Société Anonyme
Capital 250,000,000 de francs
Entièrement Versés
Agences d'Égypte:
Alexandrie, Le Caire, Port-Said
Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.
